newsitem.title: JAMAICA: Caribbean states pledge education drive.
newsitem.headline: Caribbean states pledge education drive.

text.p: Caribbean leaders said on Wednesday they wanted to improve youth education standards in a region where illiteracy is widespread.
They said a failure to bridge the education gap would make the Caribbean nations' already fragile and small economies even more vulnerable when they came to compete in a hemispheric free trade zone.

Jamaican Education Minister Burchill Whiteman, speaking at a 14-member Caribbean Community summit, said the states agreed to aim for full secondary education and to double the percentage of college age students who graduate by the year 2005.
The leaders wanted to prepare the region for entry into the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas and trade accords, he said.
Whiteman said cost "remains a challenge." The money spent by Caricom countries on education as a percentage of gross domestic product is low by world standards.
Some, like Jamaica and the smaller eastern Caribbean countries, have literacy rates of only 60 to 70 percent.
Countries attending the summit are Antigua, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Guyana, Grenada, Jamaica, Montserrat, Surinam, St. Vincent, St. Lucia, St. Kitts, and Trinidad and Tobago.
